Headline: Purpose built tourist attractions
Article_Body: Made for tourism: Iceland's mega-popular Blue Lagoon isn't a natural hot spring -- but it is conveniently close to the airport. Click through for more purpose-built tourist magnets. Hong Kong's Big Buddha: While Asia is full of ancient Buddha statues, Hong Kong's "Big Buddha" isn't one of them -- it was built in the 1990s.  Juliet's House: Shakespeare's fictional heroine draws thousands of fans to Verona, Italy, every year, where they visit a balcony she never set foot on. Day of the Dead Parade: While the Day of the Dead is widely celebrated throughout Mexico, the parade in the capital was custom-made for a James Bond film. Venice of Dalian: Numerous replica Venices have sprung up around the world, including this one in China. Checkpoint Charlie: Where the border of East and West Berlin once sat is now kitsch central, with fake soldiers in fake military uniforms. 221B Baker Street: The address given to Sherlock Holmes is now a London museum dedicated to the fictional detective. Plymouth Rock: While European settlers did arrive in Massachusetts in 1620, it's unlikely they came to this exact rock -- but that doesn't stop everyone from coming anyway.
